title: 109_hr4925
content:
The "Paul Revere Freedom to Warn Act" prohibits discrimination against whistleblowers and outlines enforcement actions, remedies, criminal penalties, and rights retained by covered individuals. It also includes provisions on the state secrets privilege, notification, and definitions. The "Paul Revere Freedom to Warn Act" prohibits discrimination against whistleblowers, including actions such as discharge, demotion, suspension, reprimand, or other personnel actions that discriminate against covered individuals. This includes denial of security clearance, revocation of security access, denial of federal contracts, or threats of such actions. Discrimination based on lawful acts by the covered individual is also prohibited. The "Paul Revere Freedom to Warn Act" protects whistleblowers from discrimination for providing information or assistance in investigations related to violations of laws, threats to security, public health, or fraud. Covered individuals are safeguarded from actions like discharge, demotion, or denial of security clearance. The "Paul Revere Freedom to Warn Act" protects whistleblowers from retaliation for reporting violations of laws, rules, or regulations, and for refusing to participate in illegal activities. SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT ACTION. A covered individual alleging discharge or discrimination in violation of section 2 can seek relief by filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor or bringing an action for de novo review by a jury in the appropriate district court if no final decision is issued within 180 days. The action is governed by rules and procedures set forth in section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code, with an exception for notification. Notification under section 42121(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code must be made to the person named in the complaint and their employer or the relevant Government entity for Federal contractors. Legal burdens of proof for actions under subsection (a)(2) are as per section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code, and the statute of limitations for such actions is 6 years from the date of the alleged violation. SEC. 4. REMEDIES.

A covered individual prevailing in any action under section 3(a) is entitled to reinstatement with the same seniority status and employment grade or pay level, compensatory damages including back pay with interest, compensation for special damages, and punitive damages not to exceed 3 times the monetary damages awarded under this Act or $5,000,000. SEC. 5. STATE SECRETS PRIVILEGE. If the Government asserts the state secrets privilege in a case under section 3(a)(2) and prevents the plaintiff from proving their claim, the court will rule in favor of the plaintiff and determine the relief. SEC. 6. CRIMINAL PENALTIES. SEC. 6. CRIMINAL PENALTIES. Any person violating section 2 may be fined, imprisoned up to 10 years, or both. The Department of Justice must submit an annual report to Congress on enforcement, detailing cases, status, and outcomes. SEC. 7. RIGHTS RETAINED BY COVERED INDIVIDUAL. This Act does not diminish the rights of covered individuals under any Federal or State law or collective bargaining agreement. Rights and remedies in this Act cannot be waived by any employment agreement. SEC. 8. NOTIFICATION. The Act must be prominently posted in applicable places of employment. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The term "covered individual" in this Act refers to an employee or member of the uniformed services serving in various government agencies, including the Department of Homeland Security and the Transportation Security Administration. The term "employee" in the Act refers to individuals working for government agencies or federally chartered entities, as defined by specific sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and title 5 of the United States Code. The term "Federal contractor" refers to a person who has entered into a contract with a government entity. The term "evidence" is defined as information meeting admissibility standards under Federal Rules of Evidence or used to support findings in government reports or decisions. The term "lawful" means not specifically prohibited by law, except for information prohibited by Federal statute or required to be kept secret for national defense or foreign affairs. "Law, rule, or regulation" refers to US laws and regulations. "Person" includes corporations, partnerships, and individuals. The term "reasonably believes" means that a disinterested observer could conclude the information constitutes evidence of misconduct. "Subcontractor" refers to any person who offers to furnish supplies or services under a contract with the Government. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. This Act will take effect 90 days after enactment and applies to pending or new administrative or judicial proceedings.
